utterances: So Lucian, you live in Moscow.
You also get out and about around Russia.
Has the economic pain been felt equally throughout the country?
I wouldn't say so.
So this week I did go out to Tula.
It's about a hundred miles south of Moscow.
It's the center of Russia's gun industry.
And there, in the Central Park, I talked to one retired librarian.
She wasn't very happy with her pension.
She says she has a part-time job to make ends meet, but she said in comparison to the 1990s when the entire Communist economy collapsed, things are much better.
And then I spoke to a 19-year-old student.
Her name is Yana Fedoseyeva, and she says she doesn't agree with older people like that at all.
They compare our economical situation with our past economical situation, how it was in Russia in '90s.
But we, my generation, we compare our economical situation with economical situation in other countries - in Europe, and America and even in Asia.
So it sounds like it's really generational, those who remember the worst times in the past and the new generation.
So normally we think a weak economy hurts the incumbent.
Putin faces an election next year.
Now, we know Russia's not exactly a vigorous democracy, but does Putin have to worry about voters like the young woman, Yana, we just heard from?
Well, for years the conventional wisdom on Russia was that once the economy goes south, when the oil money dries up, the Putin magic will sort of fizzle.

But for the last three years, he's really been able to rally Russians around the flag by saying the West is trying to hurt Russia with sanctions and that there's sort of a U.S.-led conspiracy to put Russia in its place.

I do think he's worried about the younger generation, but for now he's really relying on inertia, sort of on Russia's fear of the unknown and their memory of the economic chaos that they experienced in the past.
And so despite an ailing economy now, is he still doing well in the polls ahead of the election?
Well, just a recent poll showed that 61 percent of Russians would vote for him.
But of course, as you mentioned, this is quite a regimented system where the government controls all the TV stations, and not everyone is allowed to run against him.
Interesting.
NPR's Lucian Kim in Moscow, thank you very much.
Thanks, Lauren.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan.
As I went down and I pass by the train, the porter said, hey, boy, come on back here.
Where are you going?
I said, I'm going to get on the train.
He said, no, this is your coach, the first coach in the back of the engine.
Angie, you've seen this Third World trains?
Mm-hmm.
Where they're packed in there.
The world, at that time, did not neatly divide up into perpetrators, victims, bystanders and rescuers.
The delivery man wasn't actively involved in the resistance.
The mortician wasn't actively involved in the resistance.
And yet, when asked, they cooperated.
Ivor Pritchard says the mother he knew at home was not the larger-than-life wartime hero many see her as.
For him, she was a...
Very nice but ordinary person - I knew her as someone who was not fearless.
I remember, as a teenager, a small bat got into the house, and it scared the daylights out of her.
She was like you and me.
She just - when she found herself in extraordinary circumstances, she did the right thing.
That was Ivor Pritchard remembering his mother Marion Pritchard.
(SOUNDBITE OF HANK JONES, CHRISTIAN MCBRIDE AND JIMMY COBB'S ""ELEANOR"")
This is Day to Day, from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Imagine this.
It's broad daylight, and you can't walk down the street without worrying about getting shot.
That's the reality for people living in some sections of Los Angeles.
There are more than 40,000 gang members in L.A.
Today, we begin a two-part series on life in one of L.A.'s roughest neighborhoods.
KQED's Rob Schmitz reports.
L.A.'s Drew Street neighborhood is kind of like a 10th century fiefdom.
Its knights are Latino gang members.
Its watchtowers are the roofs of apartment buildings, where gangsters chirp each other with walkie-talkie phones whenever an outsider arrives.
Drew Street's layout makes it easy to patrol.
The neighborhood is only two blocks wide by three blocks long.
The only way you can get here is from the south.
The western border is lined with tall fences protecting warehouse yards.
To the north and east is an eight-foot tall wall topped with barbed wire.
Behind that wall is a cemetery.
This neighborhood is one big dead end, in more ways than one.
Police kill one gunman in a shootout, two others are hospitalized.
Good evening, I'm Harold Greene.
KTLA was one of several news organizations that parachuted into this neighborhood in February.
The gang members that control Drew Street had opened fire on police with an array of weapons, including an AK-47.
SWAT teams were sent in, and the neighborhood went on lockdown.
It was a rare show of police force.

But since then, the Latino gang that patrols this neighborhood, the Drew Street Crew, has regained control, and those not associated with the gang have returned to a life of anonymity because that's how you survive here.
Take it from this resident.
He's lived here most of his life, and he's still stopped by gang members who ask him where he's from.
Unidentified Man: I usually just tell them - I don't respond or say I'm not from anywhere.
And they're like, all right.
And they'll say they're gang, you know, so and so, it's my hood.
And then they'll just keep on walking.
This young man is so scared of the gang that he wishes to remain anonymous.
He's 20 years old.
He has a boyish face, short black hair and wears shorts and a sweatshirt.
He'd blend in anywhere in L.A.
He's quiet.
When he does talk, he tends to mumble, not wanting to draw a lot of attention to himself.
He lives in a rundown house on a steep hill with his wife, his infant daughter, his mother, three sisters and a brother.
He says if a young man is walking down the street here, it's a good bet he's got a gun, and that's why he drives his family everywhere, even to his sister's school, a few blocks away.
Unidentified Man: I pick them up right after school and bring them home.
You know, if they want to go to the movies, I'll drop them all off at the movies.
Not that long ago, they shot a little girl by accident.
The only reason I'm interviewing this young man outside is because his family, who's inside, isn't comfortable talking about the gangs.
In fact, during the interview, an SUV on the street below us slows to a stop.
Windows rolled down.
Two men in their 20s points at us.
I lower my voice and ask him if he knows them.
Unidentified Man: No. I don't know who they are.
Should we go inside?
Unidentified Man: I don't know.
Yeah.
As calmly as we can, we get up and go inside.
He says he hates living here.
His house has become a fortress.
But, he says, his family can't afford to move.
Unidentified Man: I love to walk my daughter down the street, and I don't feel like walking down the street with the stroller, you know?
That's one thing I wouldn't do.
(Soundbite of police radio announcement)

Less than a mile away at the LAPD Northeast Division Station, Detective Chris Vasquez says fighting crime on Drew Street is challenging because the people who live there are either part of the gang, friends of the gang, or too afraid of the gang to do anything about them.
Say they're burglarized - their house is burglarized.
They live in that neighborhood.
They have to go back to that neighborhood, so if they testify, they're going to get threatened and intimidated.
Vasquez says the police patrol Drew Street from their cars, because a foot patrol would be too dangerous.
Last year, Vasquez and his team had an idea - why don't we patrol Drew Street by camera?
A piece of equipment was put up, and then it was transformed, I believe, and it was stolen.
Then they went back and replaced that and then put the camera up, and that was shot out.
So it didn't last.
We couldn't even get it up and running.
For now, what police have done is step up undercover patrols of the area.
Officers say it's gotten quieter, but they admit the gang is still in control.
For NPR News, I'm Rob Schmitz, in Los Angeles.
And tomorrow, Rob takes us to a neighborhood where residents are fighting back.
Since 2003, StoryCorps has been recording conversations between friends and family members, everyday people telling us the stories of their lives.
Now, StoryCorps Griot is travelling the country, recording African-American stories.
Every Tuesday, we hear from the Griot project.
Today, World War II veteran Leon May.
He joined the Marine Corps in 1943, shortly after it became integrated.
May was 18 years old and had recently graduated from high school in Detroit.
Here, he tells his daughter Angela about leaving for basic training at Camp Lejeune in North Carolina.

The moderators asked about this idea of New York values, which Ted Cruz has been using to identify himself with people in places like Iowa and New Hampshire where New York City may not be that popular.
And he refined that to say not a lot of conservatives come out of Manhattan in this particular debate.
But as you say, Donald Trump then came to the defense of New York.
It was an uncharacteristic moment for Trump.
It was clearly not planned or rehearsed.
You could see his face show the thoughts coming into his mind.
And he got almost emotional talking about how New Yorkers responded after 9/11, how they suffered, the smell of death in the air.
And it was moving, and that's not what we always expect from Donald Trump and quite sincere.
Yeah, I also thought all Senator Cruz could do was just kind of nod his head.
A rare moment of silence from Ted Cruz.
Who else do you think scored well?
Marco Rubio always does well in these debates.
It's as though this is really the focal point of his campaign.

He always has prepared things to say that he gets off very spontaneously, a flurry of attacks on Ted Cruz, a flurry of attacks on Chris Christie, who did the best he could to cope with those and was certainly also a strong figure on the debate stage.
Jeb Bush, John Kasich, Ben Carson, you know, they were there but they're far behind and they're fading fast.
It seems like conservatives are on the rise in the Republican Party from one end to the other.

You know, Scott, this week, a watershed poll in The Wall Street Journal with NBC News, it shows that if you narrow the field of Republican candidates to just the top few, Trump and Cruz together have 70 percent of the vote.
So look, when the primaries are this dominated by the kind of voters we saw in the midterms of 2010 and 2014, you're going to get a conservative nominee.
And we'll be looking for a vice presidential running mate who would balance the ticket a little bit to the left.

You know, if you have to go all the way back to Ronald Reagan in 1980 to find that situation, usually the Republicans are looking for someone who would please or at least appease their right wing when it comes to a running mate.
But this year, it's going to be going back the other way.
The shoe is on the other foot.
In your estimation, is the birthplace issue serious?
These are muddy waters.
It's just not like the Obama birther issue.
That was a question of biography.
Was he born in Hawaii or not?
Get the birth certificate out there, the whole business kind of came to a halt.
This is different because we're talking about different legal interpretations of what the Constitution meant by natural born citizen.
So the lawsuits are already beginning to be filed.
